fr:title.text: Prime spectrum of primes under division

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Prime spectrum of primes under division

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A distributive lattice is Noetherian if it satisfies the equivalent conditions in Lemma .

For a distributive lattice D the following are equivalent:
Every ascending chain of ideals is stationary.
Every ascending chain of elements is stationary.
Every decreasing chain of filters is stationary. Similarly for the dual statements.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
(1), (3) \Rightarrow (2) is evident: Any ascending chain of elements p_0 \le p_1 \le \cdots induces an ascending chain of principle ideals and a decreasing chain of principle filters. For (2) \Rightarrow (1), suppose otherwise we have a strictly ascending chain of ideals I_0 \subset I_1 \subset \cdots . Then we can choose a strictly ascending chain of elements:
Take p_0 to be an element in I_0.
Suppose we have already constructed p_n\in I_n. Now let r_n be an element in I_{n+1}\backslash I_n. Take p_{n+1} to be p_n \vee r_n. This way, p_{n+1} \in I_{n+1}, and p_{n+1}\not \in I_n since r_n\not \in I_n. It follows that p_n < p_{n+1}. (2) \Rightarrow (3) is completely similar.

fr:title.text: Closure properties of Noetherian distributive lattices

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure properties of Noetherian distributive lattices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Noetherian distributive lattices are closed under finite limits, quotients, and polynomials. The latter means if D is Noetherian, then so is D[x].

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Closure under finite limits and quotients are evident from Lemma . For the polynomial D[x], it is well-known that D[x] \cong D \downarrow D is isomorphic to the order on D, which is thus also Noetherian.

fr:title.text: Noetherian distributive lattices are exactly principle ideal domains

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Noetherian distributive lattices are exactly principle ideal domains

fr:mainmatter.html:p: D is Noetherian iff every ideal in D is principle.

Suppose D is Noetherian. Let I be an ideal in D. To show I is principle, we define a sequence of elements inductively:
Choose p_0 \in I.
Suppose we have chosen p_0 < \cdots < p_n \in I. If I \neq \downarrow p_n, then we can choose q\in I with q \not \le p_n. This way, take p_{n+1} to be p_n \vee q\in I. It follows that p_n < p_{n+1}. Now since D is Noetherian, the sequence p_0 < p_1 < \cdots must stablise at some point, which implies I = \downarrow p_n for some n. Hence, I is principle.

On the other hand, suppose every ideal in D is principle. If we have an increasing sequence p_0 \le p_1 \le \cdots , then consider the ideal I = \bigcup _{n\in \omega }\downarrow p_n. By construction this is an ideal, thus it is principle I = \downarrow p. By construction, p_n \le p for all n\in \omega . However, p\in \bigcup _{n\in \omega }\downarrow p_n also implies that p \le p_n for some n\in \omega . Thus, the sequence must stablise at some point, and D is Noetherian.

fr:title.text: Prime ideals in Noetherian distributive lattices

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Prime ideals in Noetherian distributive lattices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In a Noetherian distributive lattice D, prime ideals are in bijection with meet-irreducible elements, and any element is a finite intersection of them.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We first show every ideal I in D is a finite intersection of prime ideals. Suppose there is a counterexample. Then the set \Sigma of all such ideals are non-empty. By D being Noetherian, \Sigma has a maximal element I. Since I itself cannot be prime, we can find x,y\not \in I with x \wedge y \in I. This way, x \vee I and y \vee I are proper extensions of I with (x \vee I) \cap (y \vee I) = (x \wedge y) \vee I = I. Since I is maximal in \Sigma , both x \vee I and y \vee I has a prime factorisation, which actually implies (x \vee I) \cap (y \vee I) = I also has one, contradictory. Thus, \Sigma must be empty. Now the claim follows from Proposition .

fr:title.text: Prime spectrum of natural numbers under division

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Prime spectrum of natural numbers under division

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {N} denote the distributive lattice defined by n \le m \Leftrightarrow m \mid n. In this lattice, we have n \wedge m = \mathrm {lcm}(m,n), \quad n \vee m = \mathrm {gcd}(n,m). Also, the top element is 1, and the bottom element is 0. \mathbb {N} is in fact a Heyting algebra.

fr:title.text: Prime spectrum of primes under division

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Prime spectrum of primes under division

fr:title.text: Lattices of cofinite subsets are Noetherian

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Lattices of cofinite subsets are Noetherian

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For any set X, we can construct a Noetherian distributive lattice \wp ^{\omega }_{\bot }(X) of cofinite subsets of X with the bottom element \emptyset adjointed. This lattice is evidently Noetherian. In fact, the distributive lattice \mathbb {P} in Example is isomorphic to \wp ^{\omega }_{\bot }(P) where P is the set of primes.

fr:title.text: Affine scheme for primes under division

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine scheme for primes under division

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the sub distributive lattice \mathbb {P} of \mathbb {N} described in Example , its prime spectrum can be identified as primes, plus 0. For any prime p the stalk now kills of all higher powers of p and is simply given by \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {P},p} \cong \{0 < p < 1\} \cong 2[x], and we also have \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {P},0} \cong 2. \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {P}} is thus again a linear distributive lattice.

fr:title.text: Lattices of cofinite subsets are Noetherian

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Lattices of cofinite subsets are Noetherian

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For any set X, we can construct a Noetherian distributive lattice \wp ^{\omega }_{\bot }(X) of cofinite subsets of X with the bottom element \emptyset adjointed. This lattice is evidently Noetherian. In fact, the distributive lattice \mathbb {P} in Example is isomorphic to \wp ^{\omega }_{\bot }(P) where P is the set of primes.

fr:title.text: Closure properties of Noetherian distributive lattices

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure properties of Noetherian distributive lattices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Noetherian distributive lattices are closed under finite limits, quotients, and polynomials. The latter means if D is Noetherian, then so is D[x].

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Closure under finite limits and quotients are evident from Lemma . For the polynomial D[x], it is well-known that D[x] \cong D \downarrow D is isomorphic to the order on D, which is thus also Noetherian.
